title: Market Basket launches its own beer — here’s where to buy it
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Market Basket launches 'More For Your Dollar' lager in collaboration with Vermont's Zero Gravity Beer.
The 12-pack lager is priced at $12.99 and available at MB Spirits and MB Beer & Wine locations.
The lager is sold in Massachusetts, Maine, and New Hampshire, as Market Basket undergoes leadership transition.

title: As SJC mulls involvement in public defender work stoppage, here’s where things stand
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Over 900 defendants in Massachusetts remain without representation amid public defenders' work stoppage despite a recent pay raise.
Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court is considering intervening to increase pay for court-appointed attorneys, risking a separation of powers conflict.
Legislation increased bar advocates' pay by 30%, but over 3,000 defendants were unrepresented at the peak of the crisis.

title: Reese Witherspoon visits Boston bookstore
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Reese Witherspoon visited Beacon Hill Books and Cafe in Boston, signing copies of her novel 'Gone Before Goodbye'.
Witherspoon attended a case discussion at Harvard Business School, discussing her 25-year-old film 'Legally Blonde'.
She highlighted her initiative, Reese’s Book Club, focusing on diverse, woman-centered literature.

title: GOP lawmakers pushing Healey for info on aide arrested in cocaine bust
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: GOP lawmakers challenge Gov. Maura Healey's vetting process after aide LaMar Cook's cocaine trafficking arrest.
House and Senate Minority Leaders demand disclosure on Cook's 2023 hiring and prior criminal record.
Republican gubernatorial candidates call for independent investigation into Cook's background check and hiring process.

title: 2 teens killed in New Bedford crash identified
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Gabriel Bertolino Siqueira, 17, and Anne Urbanski Santos De Carvalho, 15, were killed in a New Bedford crash.
Incident occurred around 2 a.m. on Route 140 South; both teens were ejected from a 2019 Honda Civic.
The driver, 18, from Dartmouth sustained non-life-threatening injuries; investigation into the crash is ongoing.

title: BPD releases multiple photos of baseball-capped commercial burglary suspect
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Boston police are seeking help identifying a suspect in downtown commercial burglaries starting August 21.
The suspect has been involved in similar incidents reported by Boston University, Cambridge, and Northeastern police.
Photos of the suspect have been released; he's accused of stealing credit cards, cash, and electronics.

title: Report: Mike Vrabel’s former team was ‘unwilling’ to trade with Patriots
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tennessee Titans reportedly refused to trade with New England Patriots due to owner Amy Adams Strunk's issues with coach Mike Vrabel.
Mike Vrabel was fired by the Titans after a 6-11 season with reported friction with ownership, leading to his hiring by the Patriots.
Tennessee, after firing Brian Callahan, sits at a 1-8 record post-trade deadline and recently lost to Los Angeles Chargers.

title: Following a career night, Josh Minott isn’t taking his starting role for granted
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Josh Minott scored a career-high 21 points in the Celtics' 136-107 victory over the Washington Wizards.
Minott, a former Minnesota Timberwolves player, has transitioned from a bench role to a starting position with the Celtics.
Celtics player Jaylen Brown praised Minott's energy and defense as crucial to the team's success this season.

title: Are the New England Patriots back? Here’s what 200 readers said.
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Patriots on six-game win streak; readers split on team’s progress with 43% saying they're back, 44% unsure.
Quarterback Drake Maye gaining recognition, eyed for MVP; coach Mike Vrabel praised for guiding young Patriots squad.
Concerns persist: readers note Patriots' victories mostly against weaker teams, question long-term success and resilience.

title: Questions swirl after bus aide allegedly assaults autistic student from Cambridge
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: A substitute bus aide allegedly restrained a 9-year-old autistic student and called him the devil, incident caught on video.
The Department of Children and Families is investigating; NRT Bus placed the aide on leave and prohibited from transporting Cambridge children.
Cambridge Public Schools filed child endangerment report, worked with NRT for staff training enhancement in specialized transportation.
